awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Project: Recognizing Applications of Visualization and Evaluation (RAVE) program
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution. and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. The project at Clinton College has been designed to develop a Recognition Applications of Visualization and Evaluation (RAVE) program that will assess and develop mathematics skills of freshmen at the institution.  Clinton College’s implementation of its the RAVE program will support ongoing work that explores the elements of effective programming in mathematics-based summer bridge programs that corresponds to increased enrollment, retention, and graduation of students that major in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) programs.

The RAVE program will consist of four different activities.  The activities include:  (1) the establishment of a summer bridge program that utilizes the emporium model-student engagement with technology via computer-based learning modules and focus on visualization of mathematical concepts and data; (2) the revision of curricula for entry-level gateway math courses (College Math I and II) to incorporate the emporium model; (3) the synthesis of revised, module-based mathematics instruction, goal-setting and planning skill-building instruction, and co-curricular activities to introduce students to the infrastructure of support systems on campus; and (4) the development of  faculty and peer-mentoring programs.  The activities will allow student participants to assess and bolster their skills in mathematics and computer program literacy while operating within a cohort construct, and with the advantage of early access to, and corresponding familiarity with, the campus and faculty.

This project is jointly funded by the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Clinton College RAVE program supported by the NSF Grant consisted of four objectives.

  1. Establish a summer bridge program using the emporium model, focusing on student engagement with technology through computer-based learning modules and visualization of mathematical concepts and data.

The project has demonstrated its intellectual merit through a series of positive outcomes. The initiative to enhance graduation rates and timely completion of associate and bachelor’s degrees in STEM fields for Clinton College students has proven to be successful. Notably, there has been significant progress in expanding opportunities for underprepared, underrepresented, and non-traditional students to engage in STEM disciplines. Diverse student groups have consistently received support through enhanced recruitment, learning communities, faculty and peer mentoring, career exploration, financial scholarship incentives, and a systemic transformation in mathematics education.

The project effectively supported the advancement of math, science, and technology. A variety of activities helped improve knowledge and understanding in support of teaching, training, and learning. Faculty mentors fully supported student’s academic challenges often associated with STEM degree programs.  A peer mentoring component offered more advanced STEM students an opportunity to augment the efforts of faculty in providing collaborative learning experiences for newer STEM students.

 

Significant Results:

Summer Bridge: 2021- Seven out of eight of the enrolled (87.5%) students successfully completed the first gateway course (MAT 121). One student was able to begin MAT 122 before the end of the four weeks.  (Previous pass rates in MAT 121 were less than 70%.)

Summer Bridge: 2022- Fourteen out of sixteen of the enrolled (88%) students successfully completed College Algebra I (MAT 110). (Previous pass rates in MAT 121 were less than 70%.)

Summer Bridge: 2023- Eight out of ten of the enrolled (80%) students successfully completed the first gateway course (MAT 121). Three students were moved to College Algebra, MAT 131 and successfully finished (100%) before the end of the four weeks.  (Previous pass rates in MAT 121 were less than 70%, and less than 65% in MAT 131.)

 

2. The revision of curricula for entry-level gateway math courses (College Math I and II) to incorporate the Emporium model.

Faculty curriculum innovation helped develop the 'Math Emporium'; a designated campus area (classroom, 25 computers, and faculty/staff, tutorial assistance) where students engage in a learning community environment with math as the primary focus. XYZhomework.com software was employed for student problem review in courses ranging from arithmetic review to statistics. Increased student access to interactive online support materials improved student-faculty engagement.

 

3. The synthesis of revised, module-based mathematics instruction,                      goal-setting and planning skill-building instruction, and co-curricular                 activities to introduce students to the infrastructure of support                           systems on campus.

 

We successfully installed and integrated a math problem and homework server into the Brightspace LMS platform. Additionally, we provided training to faculty and support staff on leveraging online and on-ground math training resources. The enhanced curriculum now includes a modular math course design that allows students to learn at their own pace. This instructional format tracks student progress until they demonstrate mastery in a foundational topic. 

4. The development of faculty and peer-mentoring programs. The activities will allow student participants to assess and bolster their skills in mathematics and computer program literacy and corresponding familiarity with the campus and faculty.

 

The project provided opportunities for training and professional development for faculty and student support staff. In the fall of 2023 and spring of 2024, professional development for senior faculty and support staff (Beacon Success Center) was carried out. Due to the college's pandemic-related restrictions, faculty could not attend off-campus activities. As part of the faculty development program, PI completed an intensive course in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) to improve content delivery and student engagement in math courses at all levels. Additionally, PI and CoPI participated in a weeklong National STEM Summit in Tucson, AZ, organized by the Arizona Science Foundation, and they underwent intensive faculty development training.

Established a foundation instructional practice for fall math instructions with the option for hybrid math instruction and ongoing support. 

Evidence of higher achievement for the entire student population, in addition to the STEM cohorts, has been recorded.

 

Key outcomes or other achievements:

  • Deployed and integrated a math exercise and homework server within the Brightspace LMS platform.

 

  • Implemented a homework server to offer continuous practice problems for all levels of mathematics, accessible 24/7.

 

  • Identified on-demand video instructions and eBook resources to support both online and in-person math instruction.

 

  • Trained student mentors to utilize online and in-person math tutoring resources.

 

  • Established foundational instructional practices for fall math instruction, with the option for hybrid delivery and ongoing support.

 

  • Secured institutional financial support for future Summer Bridge programs.

 

  • Both PI and Co-PI participated in the National Rural STEM Summit in June 2024, which was held in Tucson, Arizona, disseminating insights from the Emporium model of math instruction.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/14/2024
Modified by: Mohammad N Hossain
